context: [1] Cells in the renal inner medulla are normally exposed to variably high concentrations of urea and NaCl as a consequence of the urinary concentrating mechanism. [2] Systemic urea concentration also increases in uremia. [3] High urea denatures proteins, affects enzyme activity in vitro , and affects the function of cells in tissue culture. [4] In mouse renal inner medullary (mIMCD3) cells, high urea activates several mitogenic signaling proteins . [5] It increases transcription and activity of the immediate-early gene, Egr-1 , in an MEK-, ERK-, and Elk-1-dependent fashion . [6] Urea also initiates other signaling events characteristic of a receptor tyrosine kinase-mediated pathway . [7] In addition, high urea causes oxidative stress to mIMCD3 cells : (i) it increases mRNA and protein expression of growth arrest and DNA damage-inducible protein 153 (GADD153); (ii) the increases of GADD153 are completely prevented by pretreatment with the antioxidant N-acetylcysteine; and (iii) high urea decreases the level of reduced glutathione, a biological index of oxidative stress at the cellular level.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, urea is shown to have a significant impact on cellular signaling pathways, particularly in mouse renal inner medullary cells. High concentrations of urea activate mitogenic signaling proteins and increase the transcription and activity of the immediate-early gene Egr-1, which is associated with growth factor signaling. This suggests that urea can influence growth factor-related pathways, potentially affecting cell growth and function under conditions of high urea concentration, such as in uremia.
